passage_text: Dna ligase. Dna ligase. (Science: enzyme molecular biology) enzyme involved in dna replication. The dna ligase of E. Coli seals nicks in one strand of double stranded dna, a reaction required for linking precursor fragments during discontinuous synthesis on the lagging strand.

In molecular biology, DNA ligase is a specific type of enzyme, a ligase, (EC 6.5.1.1) that facilitates the joining of DNA strands together by catalyzing the formation of a phosphodiester bond. 1 DNA ligase III: complexes with DNA repair protein XRCC1 to aid in sealing DNA during the process of nucleotide excision repair and recombinant fragments. 2  Of the all known mammalian DNA ligases, only Lig III has been found to be present in mitochondria. 3  DNA ligase IV: complexes with XRCC4.

DNA Ligase Defined. DNA ligase is an enzyme that has a very critical role in the process of DNA replication and DNA repair. There are two different things going on when DNA is replicated. Let's revisit this process very briefly. DNA ligase adds on nucleotides in the usual 5' to 3' direction along the DNA strand. In addition to bridging gaps during the process of DNA replication, DNA ligase also works to do the same thing during DNA repair. When DNA is repaired, a portion of the DNA where the error or damage occurred is removed.

DNA ligase, an enzyme that can repair breaks in a strand of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) by synthesizing a bond between adjoining nucleotides. Under some circumstances the enzyme can join together loose ends of DNA strands, and in some cases it can repair breaks in ribonucleic acid (RNA). It serves as a catalyst. any of a class of enzymes that catalyze the joining together of two molecules coupled with the breakdown of a pyrophosphate bond in ATP or a similar triphosphate.
